Congratulations Brooke Rupel, Abbi Kepp and Nick Dill! 👏🏼 They are three of the eighteen Finalists in Midland Institute’s National 30-Second Pitch Competition! They were judged on defining the problem they were solving and clearly defining the solution their Business or Book provides. They had to explain the “Secret Sauce” of their product and make a call to action to their customers, choosing their words and actions carefully ... all in 30 seconds. Enjoy the victory ride Nick, Brooke and Abbi!

4...Please remember we are here for you, and we are all in this together! To stay healthy and smart, these modifications were necessary! Again, once you arrive, stay in your vehicle. No entrance will be made to the Community Center. If you have any questions or concerns, please let us know!!

--
Jeff Morrison
Neoga Community Food Pantry

Neoga CUSD #3
March 31 at 3:26 PM ·

Dear Parents and Community Members:

I hope this message finds you and your families safe and well. Today, Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker announced that remote learning in Illinois will be extended through April 30 in order to slow down the spread of COVID-19.

During this time, on-site learning will remain suspended but our schools’ commitment to learning and education will remain open and learning will continue for all students - just through a different format.

While it is not ideal, we want to assure you that at Neoga CUSD #3, our teachers and staff are fully engaged and willing to take on this new challenge and push forward with remote learning, engaging with students and continuing with our food distribution program.

I know this is not the school year that any of us imagined, but I want to thank you for your patience and understanding as we have dealt with this unprecedented situation together.

It’s important we continue to work together and support our students. Thanks again.

Sincerely,

Bill Fritcher

Neoga CUSD #3
March 26 at 12:12 PM ·

Hey, Neoga students. We miss you. So, we are going to have a parade on Monday, March 30 through the streets of Neoga so you can wave to us and say hi. Unfortunately, you won’t be able to hug us or give a high-five. Remember, you can’t gather together in large groups.

We will be leaving the NES parking lot at 12:15 on March 30 and follow the path shown on this map. We will not be throwing out candy or stopping to visit, but we want to see you. Please feel free to line the streets while keeping social distancing recommendations in mind. Come out on your porches or stand in your yards to say hello. If you don’t live in town, have someone bring you to town and park on one of the wider streets in town, on the road east of Jennings Park, or the parking lot across from the American Legion.

There are over forty staff members signed up to participate. So step outside, so your teachers can see you and say hello.

shared_text:
Rural Schools Collaborative
March 13 at 9:43 AM ·

"I have a chance to build positive relationships with not only a single student, but their whole family as I often have brothers, sisters, and cousins. I see their parents and grandparents at the student drop off line each morning. I see students transition from elementary to jr. high and I am a familiar face as they make that jump. It creates a much clearer picture for me as a teacher that I can use to help understand where the students are coming from and help them where they are at. Teaching becomes much more individualized and for me it is more meaningful and impactful." - Jordan Bear of Neoga School District, Central Illinois

Check out Jordan's full #IAmaRuralTeacher Perspective on our website here:
https://iamaruralteacher.org/profiles/jordan-bear-neoga-school-district-central-illinois

Hello, this is Bill Fritcher, Superintendent of Neoga CUSD #3. Governor Pritzker announced today that schools will remain closed through April 7. This means that the tentative return to school date is April 8.

I want to take this opportunity to thank Angie Eden, Cheryl Croy, and Barb Weir along with a host of volunteers who have worked tirelessly to provide meals this week. We will continue to run the school meal program as it operated this week. Look for some changes to the delivery schedule beginning March 30. More information is forthcoming.

Please pay attention for more School Messenger calls from this number and, if possible, pay attention to the district’s social media accounts and the district’s website (use the E-Learning tab). Also, direct any questions regarding the school closure to covid19@neogacusd3.net. Students, we miss you and hope to see your smiling faces on April 8.

Remember, this is the time to make individual sacrifices for the good of the whole. We will get through this together.

To: Neoga School Community

As you likely already know, Governor Pritzker has canceled all schools in Illinois until Tuesday, March 31. So, beginning on Tuesday, March 17 there will be no students allowed in the school and all activities are canceled. At this time, the high school play and high school prom will be postponed to later dates.

The schools will be open on Monday, March 16 from 8:00-4:00 for students and parents to retrieve personal items and learning materials. You are strongly encouraged to take textbooks and learning materials home for students to use. School staff will report to work on Tuesday, March 17 to prepare learning activities for students. These learning activities will be delivered electronically and in paper format for those without adequate internet access. More information will be provided in later communication.

This is a rapidly evolving situation with information changing often. Please be prepared for more phone calls and social media posts as information becomes available.

Bill Fritcher, Superintendent

NPP recently wrapped up what has evolved into its “busy season” — during the last four months of the year, we put on Sooeyfest, our Halloween costume contest, and our community Christmas tree lighting that grew into the Hometown Christmas celebration for 2019.

We hope that you, as a member of the community, were able to come and take part in one (or all!) of those events! We also hope that perhaps you found yourself wondering how you could get involved in what NPP is doing, whether that means being a part of these existing programs or perhaps building up something new!

That’s why we’re going to be at the Villa on 45 at 6:30 p.m. on Tuesday, March 3, for an informal meeting at which you can come to ask questions and pitch ideas about how you can fit into our organization. We’re always looking for ways to grow, but we can’t do it without you! Hope to see you then!

Neoga Hometown Christmas was nothing short of a triumph for the many NPP Christmas Committee volunteers who made the event possible under the extraordinary leadership of committee co-chairs Ashley Hartke and Mindi Haarman, and we are pleased to announce one last bit of news related to the event!

Thanks to our soup sales that day and some other donations collected during the event, we are excited to be able to present First Mid Bank & Trust in Neoga with a $500 check to be used for the benefit of the families included on their Angel Tree.

Those familiar with the Angel Tree know it is a fantastic Christmas gift-giving program the bank has facilitated for years to ensure a happy holiday for underprivileged children in our community and Neoga Partnership for Progress is proud to contribute to such a worthy cause!

(PICTURED: NPP Vice President Stephanie Finney, First Mid staff members Jessica Wooten, Pam Storm and Ketrah Dick, and NPP Christmas Committee co-chairs Mindi Haarman and Ashley Hartke.)
